He allows us to review course material and upload it in canvas. This has been helpful as I can rewatch or rewind the video as much as I
have to. Also, he encourages us to come to class if we have any questions about the class material we are learning. This provides us the
opportunity to dive deeper into the material and ask questions if we need clarification. It provides class time for us to go over
anything we do not understand. I have gone to him multiple times already throughout the semester and he took his time to explain the
material to me. He also allows us to come in to ask questions during any of the sections he teaches. This has been more convenient as I
can go during the time that best works for me and I can see him multiple times in a day if I need help with something.

I believe that this course was taught perfectly until very recently. This course was in fact taught completely asynchronously. The
materials and contents were all taught through pre–recorded videos that were uploaded by the professor. It is wrong to assume that
if a student were to go to the in–person "recitations" they would learn the course and the contents. The lectures were completely
asynchronous and this cannot be argued. It is wrong for the professor to say otherwise and inform students that the final exam will
be in–person on such short notice. This is extremely confusing for all students as they learned the course in an "online" format,
using EXCEL and other sources. Now that the final is in person, there is much confusion on if the material will be similar or not. For
a professor who I previously thought was very clear and communicative (teaching very effectively), this is shocking for me to so him
do.

I have trouble paying attention in quite a few of my business core classes and I've found that a level of "forced" engagement is
helpful. In my current financial management class, we have about 5 quiz questions per class that measure both attendance and
knowledge of the material. For not answering, we receive 0 points, answering wrong would get us 1 point, and answering correctly
would get us 2 points. Since there are so many questions, a few incorrect barely affects my grade but each time we'll work through
the problems together and there's an incentive to come to class and pay attention because we're getting points as we go. Although
this probably takes a little more effort on the instructor's part, I've found that consistent checks and incentives have forced me to pay
attention, and by paying attention, I have better command of the material and don't mentally "check–out" in class as much.

The way the homework assignments are assigned makes it very difficult. I would have done much better on the homework
assignments if they were issued in a better way. We should have until the deadline with no time limit (7 hours). This 7 hour time
limit (which counts time even if you aren't in the assignment) makes completing homework stressful because I know that I will need
to allow enough time in order to finish the whole thing at once. Whereas if there was no time constraint, I would be able to work on
the problems throughout the course of the week and most likely finish much before the deadline. I also do not like that you can't skip around the homework questions. Most people like to save the hardest questions for last, but with this style, you can't do that which also adds unnecessary stress. And lastly, it would be a MILLION times more helpful if the homework showed not only the correct answer, but the worked out steps in order to get to the right answer. Other than the way the homework is formatted, I would also designate time in class for students to work on a practice problem and then go over the solution on the board.

–change the way you did exams as for graphing problems so much time is wasted on copying the problems. next time just let students write on exams as most professors would do for this type of class. –address students concerns do not just ignore them when they ask something on the discussion board –only put material that is taught in classes on the exam –do not change up significant portions of the exam but rather just numbers, it is completely unfair for one student to get a good grade just because they had an easier question. most prof just change numbers or the order of questions. –make sure you explain to TAs what is actually being tested because every TA is telling us different things.

This professor has very poor communication skills. He is lacking in care for his students and is difficult to reach when asking questions or stating he hasn't posted HW the date he said he would. He does not read his emails. He does not know how to teach in a lecture hall and does not understand the material that he is teaching. He is an awful, unorganized professor.

The way this course is structured is terrible. This course should be structured more like Management Information Systems. Have smaller classes and a large number of sections. I know this makes scheduling much more complicated for RBS but I think students will learn much more effectively. I think if students were required to learn in this type of environment it would require students to come to class, just like MIS, and result in a better student to teacher ratio. Learning linear programming in a lecture hall with over 200 people does not work out, as you can see from the percentage of students who attended. Most students just go to recitation to learn the material in a smaller setting because in lecture hall most students get distracted with electronics, friends etc. And since most college students have the attention span of a five year old, a smaller classroom would be much better. And in reality, it did not pay to go to lectures because after going to his lectures I felt more confused. I think Professor Ely is very smart and knows what he is doing of course, but I do not like the way he teaches. If I had a question about something he would respond by explaining it and if I didnt get it the first time he would say "guys its very simple" and then look at me like that response was suppose to answer my question. Another problem is the way his slides are made. They do a great job at mirroring what is in the textbook but sometimes he doesn't highlight certain concepts in the slides that he later on tests us on. Going back to class size, throughout the semester I could tell that Professor Ely was very stressed due to the number of courses he was teaching. If RBS continues to have a large lecture hall for this course I would recommend adding a 2nd or 3rd teacher if possible. Because there were many mistakes that happened between HW assignments and exams this semester and I think it was mainly because Professor Ely had too much on his plate. If you can have two other individuals that students can go to for help then I think it would take some pressure off of him. Now on to the TA's. My TA overall was okay, but in general there was a very large discrepancy between what TA's were teaching students and what Processor Ely was. When it came to the 8 LP modeling examples most TA's only taught the first 6 problems because they said the other two were never on the exam. Later when it came time for the exam they found out that they may be on it so then they rush to teach it to us. This is not fair to the students because the purpose of learning this material is to actually learn it and be able to increase our ability to model, not for purpose of passing a exam. There really needs to be better communication between Professor Ely and his TA's because its the student who suffers in the end. Also, overall my TA was smart and very helpful. But I found at times they were not prepared for class and were trying to remember how to do problems on the fly. And many of the their lectures were not aligned to what we were learning in class (Example: were were learning lecture 5 in class, but in recitation we were still on lecture 4)

its nerve racking having your grade posted and checking it a day later to find its changed. Some students are unsure if they are exempt from the final 3 days before it. Get organized, be more prepared, and don't let it get to the point where students are nervous that their correct answer will be marked wrong on an exam. If I hadn't received A's on both exams I would have definitely argued against your answer key. Though I remain unaffected by your exam grade changes – do YOUR homework and assure the same problems won't persist next semester.
